MET Nordic Reanalysis Dataset

Source: vignettes/metno_reanal.Rmd
metno_reanal.Rmd

Author: Moritz Shore

Date: October, 2023

Last Update: October 29th, 2024

Introduction

The MET Nordic Reanalysis Dataset is a reanalysis product from the Meteorologisk institutt. You can read more about the dataset here. The MET Nordic rerun archive version 3 can be accessed using a dedicated function in miljotools. Please inform yourself on the limitations of reanalysis data before applying this dataset to your needs.

Figure 1: The spatial domain of the reanalysis dataset.

Specs

  • 1x1 km grid covering the Nordics (see Figure 1.)

  • Hourly resolution from 2012-09-01 to 2023-01-31

  • Following variables: temperature, precipitation, relative humidity, wind speed, wind direction, air pressure, cloud area fraction, short+longwave radiation (downwelling), land area fraction, and altitude

Usage

Input

To access the data for a specific region of the Nordics, you need to provide the following as input:

  1. A path to a geo-referenced shapefile (single polygon or point) of the desired area

  2. A directory where you would like to save the data (default: working directory)

  3. A starting date and time

  4. An ending date and time

Optionally, you can pass additional parameters to buffer your shapefile, choose your variables, resolution, to preview the data you are downloading, or to download the files in NetCDF format. See the man-page for more information

Figure 2. Processing the shapefile and downloading relevant grid points.

Downloading an example shape file from a public repository:

download.file(url = "https://gitlab.nibio.no/moritzshore/example-files/-/raw/main/MetNoReanalysisV3/cs10_basin.zip", destfile = "cs10_basin.zip")
unzip("cs10_basin.zip")
cs10_basin = "cs10_basin/cs10_basin.shp"

Downloading one day with the default function:

require(miljotools)
## Loading required package: miljotools
## Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggtern':
##   method           from   
##   grid.draw.ggplot ggplot2
##   plot.ggplot      ggplot2
##   print.ggplot     ggplot2
download_folder <- get_metno_reanalysis3(
area = cs10_basin,
fromdate = "2015-01-01 00:00:00",
todate = "2015-01-02 00:00:00", 
area_buffer = 1500,
preview = T
)
## MILJOTOOLS >> 'grid_resolution' not chosen, defaulting to 1x1km grid...

## integral_of_surface_downwelling_shortwave_flux_in_air_wrt_time

## finished! files have been written to: 
## C:/Users/mosh/Documents/GIT/miljotools/vignettes/met_no_dl_20241030130037

As output you will receive a separate .csv file for each grid point. This .csv file contains the meteorological data as a time series, with a column for each variable. Additionally one metadata file is created listing the properties of each grid point (such as coordinates)

Note: Currently, this function must request the data from met.no server on an hour-basis. This means that for each year to download, 8760 requests must be made to the server. This is rather slow, and as such the download can take quite a few hours. We are working with met.no to improve this situation.

Converting to Daily

If you would prefer to have your data in a daily format, you can use the reanalysis3_daily() function. This function merely requires the path of the download folder as created by get_metno_reanalysis3(). You can pass a precision parameter which determines to which decimal point the hourly data will be averaged / summed to.

We can convert the data set to daily resolution as follows:

daily_path = reanalysis3_daily(path = download_folder,
                               outpath = "../vignettes",
                               verbose = T)
## reading files..
## loading files into memory..
## re-calculating to daily..
## copying metadata..
## writing files..
## Conversion finished, files written to:
##  ../vignettes/met_no_dl_20241030130037_daily

Creating SWAT+ input

If you would like to generate SWAT+ meteo input from the daily data as downloaded get_metno_reanalysis3() and converted from reanalysis3_daily(), you can use the reanalysis3_swatinput() function. This function, depending on the parameters given to it, will generate your station files and weather generator. It also can update your SWAT+ input files to match the new weather stations, or update your .sqlite database. To do this, the function heavily utilizes SWATprepR which needs to be installed before use. This can be done here.

We can create input files for the SWAT+ model using the daily files. For this we will need to get a SWAT+ setup to modify, which we will download from the same GitLab Repository. Additionally, we will download some pre-downloaded reanalysis files generated by miljotools.

download.file(url = "https://gitlab.nibio.no/moritzshore/example-files/-/raw/main/MetNoReanalysisV3/cs10_txt.zip", destfile = "cs10_txt.zip")
unzip("cs10_txt.zip")
download.file(url = "https://gitlab.nibio.no/moritzshore/example-files/-/raw/main/MetNoReanalysisV3/krak_daily.zip", destfile = "krak_daily.zip")
unzip("krak_daily.zip")
example_daily_files = "krak_daily"
cs10_txt_path = "cs10_txt"

Now we are ready to run the function:

reanalysis3_swatinput(
  path = example_daily_files,
  swat_setup = cs10_txt_path,
  write_wgn = T,
  verbose = T
)
## backing up SWAT directory in ./miljotools_swat_backup 
## loading SWATprepR
## 
## Loading required namespace: SWATprepR
## Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggpp':

Reanalysis to SWAT+ input pipeline

The aforementioned three function can be linked together with the swat_weather_input_chain(). It simply runs the three functions in parallel, allowing you to generate and apply weather data to your SWAT+ project with one line of code. For run-timeâ€™s sake, the following code is not executed here.

swat_weather_input_chain(
  area = "cs10_basin/cs10_basin.shp",
  swat_setup = "cs10_txt",
  from = "2013-01-01 00:00:00",
  to = "2022-12-31 00:00:00"
)

NCDF4 and CWATM

To provide input files for the CWATM model, downloading the reanalysis files needed to be done in such a way that the original NetCDF4 format (*.nc) was retained. This can be done using the regular get_metno_reanalysis3() function, if the flag ncdf is set to TRUE as shown below:

cwatm_vars <- c(
  "precipitation_amount",
  "air_temperature_2m",
  "relative_humidity_2m",
  "air_pressure_at_sea_level",
  "integral_of_surface_downwelling_shortwave_flux_in_air_wrt_time",
  "integral_of_surface_downwelling_longwave_flux_in_air_wrt_time",
  "wind_speed_10m"
)


download_path = get_metno_reanalysis3(
  area = cs10_basin,
  mn_variables = cwatm_vars,
  fromdate = "2015-01-01 00:00:00",
  todate = "2015-01-03 00:00:00",
  ncdf = TRUE, 
  preview = F
)

The NetCDF4 files can be converted to daily resolution using the cwatm_hourly_to_daily_ncdf4() function. Currently this function is hard coded to only work with the CWATM variables (hence the function prefix). This should be resolved over time to handle any reanalysis variables (#24).

In this demonstration, we will again use example files to reduce run times

download.file(url = "https://gitlab.nibio.no/moritzshore/example-files/-/raw/main/MetNoReanalysisV3/ncdf_example.zip", destfile = "ncdf4_example.zip")
unzip(zipfile = "ncdf4_example.zip")
daily_path = cwatm_hourly_to_daily_ncdf4(inpath = "ncdf_example",
                            outpath = "ncdf_daily",
                            verbose = T)
## miljoðŸŒ¿tools cwatm_hourly_to_daily_ncdf4 >> converting day... 20150101 (33.33%)miljoðŸŒ¿tools cwatm_hourly_to_daily_ncdf4 >> converting day... 20150102 (66.67%)
## Warning in cwatm_hourly_to_daily_ncdf4(inpath = "ncdf_example", outpath =
## "ncdf_daily", : last day of download is incomplete, skipping this day
## 
## miljoðŸŒ¿tools cwatm_hourly_to_daily_ncdf4 >> finished!

To convert the daily ncdf4 files into CWATM compatible input files, one can use the convert_to_cwatm() function (working prototype, nearly finished).

convert_to_cwatm(input = daily_path, output = "cwatm", verbose = T)
## miljoðŸŒ¿tools convert_to_cwatm >> creating output directory...

Having a look at the data:

ncfile <- ncdf4::nc_open("cwatm/tasmax_nor2.nc")
tasmax <- ncdf4::ncvar_get(ncfile, "tasmax_nor2")
ncdf4::nc_close(ncfile)
image(tasmax[,,1])

Cleanup 

require(dplyr)
## Loading required package: dplyr
## 
## Attaching package: 'dplyr'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     filter, lag
## The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
## 
##     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
unlink(c("krak_daily", "cwatm", "cs10_txt", "cs10_basin", "miljotools_swat_backup", "ncdf_daily", "ncdf_example"), recursive = T)

list.files(pattern = "met_no_dl*") %>% unlink(recursive = T)

file.remove(c("krak_daily.zip", "cs10_txt.zip", "cs10_basin.zip", "ncdf4_example.zip"))
